contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Rudolph Minkowski |image = Minkowski,Rudolph 1934 London.jpg|thumb|center |birth_date = {{birth date|1895|5|28}} |birth_place = [[Strasbourg]], [[German Empire]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1976|1|4|1895|5|28}} |death_place = [[Berkeley, California]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[Germany]] |ethnicity = |field = [[astronomy]] |work_institutions = [[Palomar Observatory]] |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[supernova]]e |influences = |influenced = |prizes = [[Bruce Medal]] in 1961 |religion = }} '''Rudolph Minkowski''' (born '''Rudolf Leo Bernhard Minkowski'''; May 28, 1895 – January 4, 1976) was a German-American [[astronomer]]. Minkowski was the son of Marie Johanna Siegel and physiologist [[Oskar Minkowski]].<ref>[http://books.google.ca/books?id=ACQvAQAAIAAJ&q=Marie+Siegel++Minkowski&dq=Marie+Siegel++Minkowski&hl=en&redir_esc=y]</ref> His uncle was [[Hermann Minkowski]]. Rudolph studied [[supernova]]e and, together with [[Walter Baade]], divided them into two classes (Type I and Type II) based on their spectral characteristics. He and Baade also found optical counterparts to various [[radio astronomy|radio]] sources. He headed the [[National Geographic Society – Palomar Observatory Sky Survey]], a photographic atlas of the entire northern sky (and down to [[declination]] -22°) up to [[apparent magnitude|magnitude]] 22. He co-discovered the [[Apollo asteroid]] [[1620 Geographos]], and also discovered [[Planetary Nebula M2-9]]. He won the [[Bruce Medal]] in 1961. The crater [[Minkowski (crater)|Minkowski]] on the [[Moon]] is named after him and his uncle. {| border=1 cellpadding=5 |+ [[Asteroid]]s discovered: 1 | [[1620 Geographos]] || September 14, 1951 || with [[Albert George Wilson|A.
